Description: This gemstone depicts Cheiron resting on his hind legs underneath a tree on the right. He wears a long beard, and his hair is arranged in a thick roll around his head. A loose piece of cloth or animal skin hangs over his right shoulder. He reaches out to grasp the lyre that the nude boy holds in his right arm in order to instruct him. The musical education of Achilles by Cheiron is a particularly popular theme on gems. The first literary reference to the theme is Roman (Ovid, Ars Amatoria 1.11), but Achilles' lyre-playing is already mentioned in the Iliad (9.186-89).

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Heroes: Mortals and Myths in Ancient Greece
Exhibitions.Textblock: Heroes: Mortals and Myths in Ancient Greece. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Frist Center for the Visual Arts, Nashville; San Diego Museum Of Art, San Diego; Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation (USA), New York. 2009-2011.

Medium: red jasper, set in a modern gold ring
Provenance: Chesterfield Collection [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Bessborough Collection, no. 31c [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Tassie Collection, no. 9207 [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Marlborough Collection, no. 339 [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, New York, by purchase [Dikran Kelekian as agent]; Sadie Jones (Mrs. Henry Walters), New York, 1931, by inheritance; Sale, Joseph Brummer, New York, 1942; Walters Art Museum, 1942, by purchase.
Title: Gem with Achilles and Cheiron
